2:45 That description is wrong, it's not just the Generator that gets better and better, it's the Discriminator that gets better and better too. Reaching an "equilibrium" doesn't mean the discriminator can't tell real from fake, that's not an equilibrium at all... in fact that's quite the opposite. Equilibrium means they both have a similar win/loss ratio. 50% of the time, the discriminator will tell real from fake, 50% of the time it won't.

GANs are described as a two-player zero-sum game. As you'd expect from hearing the term zero-sum, each participants' win/loss ratio is balanced (there's an equilibrium). This is what "adversarial" means in Generative Adversarial Networks. Both the discriminator and the generator compete against each other and they are trained using backpropagation of the same training data.

The discriminator is just a simple classifier. Whether it correctly classifies the data or not, it uses backpropagation to adjust (change the weights of) each neuron (a set of weights and an activation/squashing function, e.g. a sigmoid function). It does this over many training epochs (pass through of a dataset) until the discriminator is able to properly classify a certain percentage of test data during the validation stage of training. This percentage is known as the accuracy. So it will train based on the initial data set + the newly generated data to become an improved version of itself, and it will continue training until a goal accuracy (%) is achieved based on a certain learning rate (how likely it is to adapt/change based on differences in the data). These are all configured by the programmer, or more accurately the computer scientist.

What makes a "deepfake" good or bad isn't the "quality of the neural net", it's the training. Data is king, that's why Google and everybody else wants your data. Sure, there are new techniques/algorithms that might make the task easier or approach it from a different angle, but that isn't necessarily better or worse. What makes a "good deepfake" better than an "amateur deepfake" is the configuration of the GANs. Not everybody is willing to pay for Microsoft Azure's or Google Cloud's AI platform to make use of their processing power, so instead "amateur deepfakes" use GANs that are configured with less strict accuracy and training requirements to achieve arbitrarily reasonable results within an reasonable amount of time on consumer hardware. The very same GAN can be used on a much more powerful server and achieve much better results, and likewise a consumer pc can achieve much better results by simply giving it more processing time.

And on a side note, relying on metadata is terrible. Not only is that a privacy concern, but clips get re-encoded, snipped, and mashed up all the time. As the description implies, this method relying on the metadata only works on the original raw footage, unless of course you're spoofing the metadata in which case that presents a whole 'nother set of issues. If proving a video is real requires metadata, that means either the public needs access to that so they can also verify it independently, or we have to take a third party's word for it which makes it pointless in the first place. If it's made public, we then have access to potentially personal info, and the person behind the camera basically just doxxed themselves at that point.

AI training is directly dependant on the ammount of data used to train the algorithms. To make something look or sound realistic you need multiple hours of clean, uninterrupted audio and video and /weeks/ of training and tuning for it to fool anybody. That's why the primary examples running around are from public figures. They constantly appear on screen so getting enough data is simple enough. An average person on the other hand simply will not become a target due the difficulty of gathering enough information for the neural network to work with.
Now is when you say that the whole video has been made using deepfake.

It seems to me that "we" (society) will need device manufactures to checksum and digitally sign content as it's being collected.




There would then need to be a digital chain of custody (block chain?) saved in a service that would allow legitimate content editors to re-sign anything they manipulated while maintaining a reference to the original.




Finally, web browsers and other applications that display content would be able to flag 'unsigned' images/videos as suspect or block them entirely.
Faking voices is a real thing now. Have you listened to the Samuel L. Jackson version of Alexa that Amazon released about a month ago?

Ten years, tops, and audios/videos will only have the same trustworthiness as your average gossip unless they have a digital signature so complex and hard-to-fake that it probably doesn't even exist yet. Imagine the chaos this will cause in courts initially.

Jesus.

We already have a huge problem in our society with people believing things that are totally out of line with reality because lots of people have little or no critical-thinking skills regarding what they *read*. (Examples: anti-vaxxers, sov-citizens, &c.)

What is going to happen when people can't rely on the truth of what they see without applying heavy critical skills? Or -- infinitely worse, deciding that they have the power and the right to reshape the presentation of reality to suit their own agenda.

I mean this is straight out of Orwell -- fictitious worlds are the essence of totalitarianism. Except that even Orwell could not have imagined that everyone with tech and an agenda becomes her own Minitrue. At that point, the Orwellian -- brutal top-down control of reality -- and the Huxleyan dystopia -- a society amusing itself to death -- merge.

It's all well and good for a channel like SciShow to tell its self-selected audience to brush up on their media literacy skills. But the problem will come from those who just didn't -- or didn't want to -- get that memo. We've already seen how hard it is to chase down Web-based mis- and disinformation.

Smartphones create fakes when you take an actual picture using computational photographic techniques to enhance the image from the sensor before it gets saved.
One common use of these techniques is bokeh, blurring out the background to bring the subject to the eye. Using computational photographic techniques produces an image that is comparable to what deepfake techniques are doing, that image from your smartphone may be indistinguishable from a fake derived from that photo due to the enhancements already in play on the original image.

honestly, it's kinda annoying how audio is basically all but ignored by the devs of neural nets. I'm still waiting for that ANN that would allow you to make audioclip A sound like the audioclip B. Image processing networks are able to do this for a really long time now... I'd imagine it would be a very useful tool for creative audio FX.
It is inherent to the technology of GANs that every technique to identify them can be used to make them better and avoid that identification.

I think audio deepfakes will have their limitations just like synth sounds in music programmes. Overtones are a complex matter - and you cannot make flute sound like electric guitar or a trumpet for that reason. You can at best manipulate and make something that sound somewhat similar but the fake will never be as good as the original because the high frequency overtones are so complex.


In the real world you also have early reflections, but on most crappy synth recordings you will not have that - which in turn makes the sound sound more artificial without it. In a blindtest you will be able to differ between a real trumpet playing from a recording of trumpet with no early reflections.

Let's not forget that deepfake technology can be used not only by people creating undesirable or controversial footage of another person for purposes of defamation, but also by people creating appealing "past" footage of themselves for self-promotion/defense/glorification purposes.
Imagine a powerful politician being caught out and challenged on footage of statements made in the past regarding a certain issue, which in retrospect have now become controversial due to an Overton shift, for example. Now this past footage can be proclaimed to be "fake", while a "real" version, which is in line with the politician's current, more popular stance, can be artificially generated by the politician's team.
The game works both ways.

Despite the fact that many YouTubers simply use the program as a form of entertainment to make a sum of people laugh or to shock them with their editing skills, Deepfakes are still a very questionable piece of technology for me. I spend a fair amount of time programming and I just have to say this, this is far beyond anything that I'm willing to work on. Well, I might just use it once or twice for shits and giggles, but nothing over that. It's such a strange and wonderful advance in technology, although it can easily ruin a life or obscure evidence in criminal cases. It baffles me that we've gone so far, I'm thinking that by the time we reach the 3000's videos of people and videos of computer-generated programs will be nearly indistinguishable. Where can we draw the line? Honestly, the mere concept of such an intelligent and impressive program can easily bring about the end if it gets into the wrong hands.
